entry.title: Re: Free of Charge Material from Customer with Freight an...
entry.content:
I could see the below challenges in your process

  • FOC Raw Materials: Received without invoice value, tracked only by quantity.
  • Associated Costs: Freight and Import Duty are incurred and need to be reflected in product costing.
  • Standard Cost Estimate: Should include these costs in the cost structure of Semi-Finished Goods (SFG) and Finished Goods (FG).

Below are the approaches which you can explore

Even if the material is FOC, you can still create a Purchase Order (PO) with zero material value. Add Freight and Import Duty as condition types in the PO (e.g., FRB1 for freight, ZIMP for import duty). These condition types can be configured to post to specific cost elements.

Use Planned Delivery Costs in the PO to record freight/import duty. These costs can be posted to a cost center or internal order using account assignment. Ensure these costs are not capitalized to inventory but are available for cost analysis.

In SAP CO-PC, define a costing sheet that includes surcharges for freight and import duty. Link these surcharges to cost elements that capture the actuals from the PO or customs. This allows the standard cost estimate to include these costs even if the RM is non-valuated.

Create a phantom material or auxiliary material to represent the FOC RM. Assign freight/import duty costs to this material manually or via costing sheet. Include this in the BOM of the SFG/FG so the cost flows into the final product.

Your configuration approach should be

  • Ensure cost elements for freight and import duty are created and assigned to appropriate cost component structure.
  • Use valuation class and account determination to route costs correctly.
  • Consider using Activity Types if freight is internal (e.g., company trucks).

So with the above, the outcome is by using planned delivery costs, costing sheets, and manual cost component planning, your costing team can ensure that Freight and Import Duty for FOC raw materials are included in the standard cost estimate‚Äîeven though the material itself is non-valuated.

entry.title: Re: Restrict users from editing a parked invoice
entry.content:
To achieve this, you‚Äôll need to modify the business role assigned to the users by adjusting the access category and restriction types in the Maintain Business Roles app.

Open the ‚ÄúMaintain Business Roles‚Äù app in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Identify the role assigned to users who should not edit parked invoices. Navigate to the ‚ÄúMaintain Restrictions‚Äù tab for that role. Locate the business catalog related to supplier invoice processing (e.g., SAP_FIN_BC_AP_INV_PROC_PC). Under Access Categories, set Write Access ‚Üí No Access or Restricted (depending on whether you want full block or conditional access). Read Access ‚Üí Unrestricted (so they can still view parked invoices).

In Restriction Types, look for fields like Invoice Status, Company Code, Document Type, Posting Status. Set these to restrict editing based on parked status or other relevant criteria.

entry.title: SAP FICO Career Scope in India 2025: Opportunities, Growth & Skills You Need
entry.content:
Introduction

If you‚Äôve ever wondered how large companies manage their finances seamlessly, there‚Äôs a good chance SAP FICO is behind it. As digital transformation accelerates across Indian enterprises, best SAP FICO career opportunities are booming in 2025. Whether you‚Äôre a student exploring future-proof career options or a fresher seeking specialization, SAP FICO offers the perfect blend of technology, finance, and business understanding.

In this guide, we‚Äôll explore everything you need to know about SAP FICO‚Äôs career scope in India‚Äîwhat skills you need, how much you can earn, what the job roles look like, and how to start learning it the right way.

What is SAP FICO and Why It is having career scope in India 2025?

SAP FICO stands for Financial Accounting (FI) and Controlling (CO)‚Äîtwo of the most critical modules in the SAP ERP suite. It helps organizations manage their financial transactions, budgeting, and internal cost control.

In simple terms, SAP FICO professionals are the bridge between business finance and technology. As Indian companies migrate from legacy systems to SAP S/4HANA, skilled FICO consultants are becoming indispensable.

Why it‚Äôs trending in 2025:

  • India‚Äôs digital finance landscape is expanding rapidly.
  • SMEs and large corporations are moving to cloud-based ERP systems.
  • SAP-certified professionals earn some of the highest packages in enterprise IT.
  • Global consulting firms (like Deloitte, Capgemini, Accenture) are actively hiring SAP FICO specialists.

Career Opportunities in SAP FICO

  1. SAP FICO Consultant

The most common role, responsible for configuring and maintaining the SAP FICO module according to client needs. Consultants also handle system upgrades, business process mapping, and end-user training.

Average Salary: ‚Çπ6‚Äì12 LPA for mid-level professionals.

  1. SAP FICO Analyst

Analysts focus on data reporting, financial reconciliations, and supporting business decisions through analytics. They act as the link between finance teams and IT departments.

Average Salary: ‚Çπ4‚Äì8 LPA depending on experience and company type.

  1. SAP FICO End User

End users work within the finance departments of companies using SAP. They perform day-to-day activities like posting entries, generating reports, and monitoring transactions.

Average Salary: ‚Çπ3‚Äì6 LPA (ideal starting point for fresh graduates).

  1. SAP FICO Trainer or Instructor

With demand for FICO training increasing, becoming an SAP FICO tutor is another rewarding path. Trainers earn both through corporate batches and online teaching platforms.

Average Salary: ‚Çπ8‚Äì15 LPA (or ‚Çπ800‚Äì‚Çπ2,000/hour for freelance trainers).

SAP FICO Career Growth Path

A career in SAP FICO is not static. With continuous upskilling, you can move up the ladder:

  1. Junior Consultant (0‚Äì2 years) ‚Äì Learn configurations, testing, and documentation.
  2. Senior Consultant (2‚Äì5 years) ‚Äì Handle implementation and client interactions.
  3. Team Lead / Project Manager (5‚Äì8 years) ‚Äì Oversee end-to-end SAP projects.
  4. Solution Architect (8+ years) ‚Äì Design integrated solutions across SAP modules.
  5. SAP Practice Head / Functional Lead (10+ years) ‚Äì Lead enterprise-wide strategy and consulting.

Skills Required to Build a Strong SAP FICO Career

Skill Type

Example / Description

Technical Skills

SAP FICO configuration, S/4HANA migration, integration with MM/SD/PP modules

Finance Knowledge

Accounting principles, cost center management, asset accounting

Analytical Thinking

Problem-solving, business analysis, and data interpretation

Communication

Client coordination, documentation, and presentation

Certifications

SAP Certified Application Associate (S/4HANA for Financial Accounting)

Pro Tip: Many successful consultants start with accounting degrees (B.Com, MBA Finance, CA-Inter) and then specialize in SAP FICO.

SAP FICO Learning Roadmap for Students

  1. Step 1: Build foundational knowledge in Accounting & ERP concepts.
  2. Step 2: Learn the core SAP FICO modules (General Ledger, Accounts Payable, Cost Center Accounting).
  3. Step 3: Practice hands-on using SAP S/4HANA trial systems.
  4. Step 4: Enroll in advanced courses with practical case studies.
  5. Step 5: Earn certification and build your portfolio with mini projects.
  6. Step 6: Apply for internships or freelance projects to gain experience.

üëâ Tip: Compare verified SAP FICO tutors in online on FindMyGuru to learn from experienced trainers who provide real-time project exposure.

Why SAP FICO Is a Safe & Future-Proof Career in India

  • Evergreen Domain: Finance and controlling are vital for every business.
  • Cloud Adoption: S/4HANA Cloud is driving new implementations.
  • Global Demand: Opportunities across India, Middle East, Europe, and North America.
  • High ROI on Learning: Short learning curve but high salary potential.
  • Cross-domain Mobility: You can transition into SAP CO, MM, or S/4HANA Finance roles later.

SAP FICO vs Other SAP Modules ‚Äì Which Should You Choose?

If you have a commerce or finance background, SAP FICO is undoubtedly the best starting point.

FAQs About SAP FICO Career

  1. Is SAP FICO a good career for beginners?
    Yes. Even fresh graduates from commerce or MBA backgrounds can start as end users or junior consultants. With consistent learning, you can grow into consulting or management roles.
  2. How long does it take to learn SAP FICO?
    Typically, 3‚Äì6 months of structured training with practical projects is sufficient to become job-ready, provided you have basic accounting knowledge.
  3. What is the future of SAP FICO in India after 2025?
    The demand will continue to grow as more companies shift to SAP S/4HANA. Certified consultants will have global opportunities and higher salary packages.
  4. Can non-commerce students learn SAP FICO?
    Yes. While finance basics help, students from technical backgrounds can also learn with the right guidance and structured training.
  5. How can I find the best SAP FICO trainer?
    You can compare verified SAP FICO tutors and institutes on FindMyGuru, check reviews, and book demo sessions before enrolling.

Conclusion

The best SAP FICO career landscape in India is brighter than ever in 2025. With digital transformation touching every industry‚Äîfrom manufacturing to retail‚Äîcompanies need experts who can translate financial data into business decisions.

If you‚Äôre passionate about finance, technology, and problem-solving, SAP FICO can be your gateway to a stable, high-paying career.

entry.title: Re: SAP SF Onboarding External User First Access Language
entry.content:
Hello,

We are about to go live with Onboarding 2.0 and this issue had come up in our testing as well. There is a definite product gap in this mapping between Recruiting and Onboarding. We had to create a custom required picklist field on our candidate profile for applicants to select one of the langauges that we are currently supporting for translations. This field would ultimately be passed when we initiate onboarding so that the proper translated email and expereince would happen for the onboardee.

Its not an ideal workaround as it may be viewed as limiting other languages but it was the only we could it to function.

I hope this helps.

Paddy Koltsaklis

entry.title: Some ACDOCA entries missing in ACDOCU after GRPL (Release Universal Journals)
entry.content:
Hi everyone,
we‚Äôre using S/4HANA On-Premise Group Reporting and performing the release via the GRPL (Release Universal Journals) process. In general, we can see that most G/L accounts ‚Äî such as bank accounts and trade receivables ‚Äî are transferred completely and correctly from ACDOCA to ACDOCU. However, for some accounts like advances given to suppliers or finished goods, we‚Äôve noticed that certain records are missing in ACDOCU. Even though these accounts belong to the same ledger, period, version, and G/L setup, only part of the ACDOCA entries are released ‚Äî while specific document lines are skipped during the data load. When we trace the skipped document numbers in ACDOCA, we also find that their offsetting credit entries (for example, trade payables) are missing in ACDOCU as well. This is one example, but we‚Äôve identified a few similar cases. FS Item mapping and all other configuration steps seem correct, and we‚Äôve also executed the Realign Group Reporting Preparation Ledger job as part of our checks. Has anyone experienced this kind of issue ‚Äî where certain ACDOCA document lines are silently skipped during the GRPL release ‚Äî or knows what could cause this behavior?

entry.title: Want to Earn More Badges? Let‚Äôs Discuss!
entry.content:
Healthy discourse is a critical component for any community, and our latest badge progression set is designed specifically for members who kick these conversations off by starting discussions. 

As with the other progression badges that we introduced recently, this set will contain five badges that will be awarded retroactively ‚Äì meaning, if you‚Äôve already initiated discussions in the community, you may get one or more badges tomorrow (Thursday, October 9). You‚Äôll earn the first badge for the first discussion you started, the second for starting three discussions, the third for starting ten, and the fourth for starting twenty. If you‚Äôve been especially chatty, you may even get the fifth badge ‚Äì awarded for starting fifty discussions! 

If you‚Äôre unfamiliar with discussions in SAP Community, you‚Äôll find several lively ones within our various groups. We have groups for locations around the world, fun activities (such as Devtoberfest), common interests (including the community‚Äôs very own Welcome Corner), and more. 

Unlike the Q&A boards (where members seek solutions to their problems), discussions generally focus on an open topic and allow other members to share their thoughts and opinions. There‚Äôs no right answer ‚Äì just an invitation to participate in a friendly chat. 

If you‚Äôd like to start a discussion, first find a group that interests you. Click the big blue button near the top of the group‚Äôs page to join. You can‚Äôt miss it. (Note that some private groups may require that their owners approve your request to join, but you can join any public group right away with the click of the button.) 

If you try to start a discussion before joining a group, the option will be grayed out. 

 

Joining the group opens the option to start a discussion.  

 

While we understand that our badge enthusiasts may be eager to complete this new set quickly, please make sure that you only start discussions that are relevant to the corresponding group(s) in which you want to post ‚Äì and that the discussions are meant to encourage group members to participate in the conversation. Starting an off-topic discussion may earn you a badge, but it won‚Äôt generate any interest. A group owner or curator may even opt to remove the discussion if it doesn‚Äôt fit the group‚Äôs purpose. Best to spend some time in a group to get to know it and its members before starting a discussion there. 

Once you‚Äôre comfortable with a group (and feel confident you can strike up appealing discussions in it), take advantage of the opportunity to earn badges from the new set. Or if you‚Äôre already active in groups (with several discussions to your credit), you may earn one or more badges when we introduce the new set tomorrow. 

Want to know how many badges from this set you‚Äôre entitled to? Here‚Äôs what you need to do.  

Log in to SAP Community, then select ‚ÄúMy content.‚Äù 

 

Scroll down to the ‚ÄúPrivate Stats‚Äù section of your content page and look for the ‚ÄúDiscussions Started‚Äù entry. That number will help you determine how many badges coming your way tomorrow. For example, for the member below, he can expect badges for starting one, three, and ten discussions ‚Äì as his fourteen discussions are more than enough to earn him the first three badges in the set. He‚Äôll need to be a little more active in group discussions to earn the last two (for twenty and fifty discussions, respectively). Still, he‚Äôs well on his way to completing the set! 

We‚Äôll need a few hours to assign the badges tomorrow, and we‚Äôll award them one at a time from the lowest to highest. Our friend above can expect three notifications (one for each badge that he earned, beginning with the badge for starting his first discussion), and you can expect one or more yourself if you‚Äôve been actively starting discussions in the community. (If your badges haven‚Äôt shown up by Friday the 10th), make sure to log out and in again.) 

Don‚Äôt forget: These badges are meant to thank the members who take the time to make positive contributions to SAP Community. Answer a question, write a blog post that educates other members, leave a kudo on content that you enjoy, begin a friendly discussion. Each of those actions helps create a healthier, happier community ‚Äì and can earn you badges that show our appreciation.

entry.title: Re: How to control PO Output types based on Plant and Sto...
entry.content:
Hello @Subbaka11 

You need to setup PO output determination by plant and storage location. The output determination uses condition technique. The same one that is used in pricing - see SAP Help Introduction to the Condition Technique:

 

Basically, you need to create an access table with plant and storage location, then assign the table to access sequence, then assign the access sequence to output type. This way you will be able to define output determination conditions per plant and storage location.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: One Hour, One Habit, One Champion: Kunal Bansal‚Äôs Lifelong Learning Story üèÜ
entry.content:
Ask Kunal Bansal what the most powerful skill in his career has been, and he won‚Äôt say coding, consulting, or communication - he‚Äôll say consistency. Every single day, no matter where he is, he dedicates one hour to learning. That one habit has not only shaped his expertise but also inspired hundreds of others to start their own learning journeys. 

Q: Paint us a picture of who you are beyond work. What would we find you doing on a Saturday morning? What‚Äôs something about you that might surprise your colleagues? 

Saturday mornings start with badminton with friends and afternoons mentoring rural students. Supporting underprivileged learners keeps me grounded and reminds me why learning matters. 

I spend at least an hour daily learning. It‚Äôs as natural as breathing, but far more rewarding. Mentoring isn‚Äôt just a hobby; it‚Äôs my passion. Networking and talking to people across industries taught me business processes, the foundation that made SAP technology click for me. 

Q: Take us inside a typical business day. What makes you excited to get up in the morning, and what frustrates you? 

My day begins with a workout at the gym. My favorite and happiest hour. After that come leadership calls on people and skill management for our SAP CX practice, followed by client project calls. 

Tea, lunch, and walks with colleagues mix jokes, work talk, and wisdom. 
What frustrates me? Seeing colleagues stuck in a non-learning, non-growth mindset. 
What excites me? Helping them flip the switch and grow. 

Q: Tell us about the moment you decided to learn SAP. What sparked that decision? 

I started my career in the SAP Student Training and Rotation program - clueless, wide-eyed, and wondering how to survive in this massive ocean. My mentor, Ramakrishna, told me something that shaped my entire journey: ‚ÄúStart with basics and learn business processes, not systems.‚Äù 

Q: What was your biggest ‚Äòaha!‚Äô moment? 

Back in 2016, I was working on SAP CRM and SAP Marketing Cloud. When I finally understood the CRM business process, the dots connected. 

I realized that technology wasn‚Äôt just moving data. It was orchestrating the heartbeat of a business. That shift turned me into a trusted advisor to customers and the go-to person for technical and business challenges. 

Q: What was the hardest part of your learning journey? 

Opening SAP Learning Hub for the first time felt like entering a massive library without a map - overwhelming! 

I remembered my mentor‚Äôs advice: start from basics, learn business processes first. Once I did, the chaos turned into clarity. That persistent learning turned me from a rookie into a recognized community voice. 

Q: What surprised you most about the learning process? 

Answering Q&A and writing blogs on SAP Community accelerated my learning more than I expected. 

Contributing consistently for over seven years helped me become a community influencer and built my personal brand as a subject matter expert which eventually led to my selection as an SAP Champion.  

Q: What‚Äôs something you can do now that you couldn‚Äôt before? 

Previously, I used to explain SAP technology in dense technical jargon, regardless of the audience. Now, I adapt my speech according to the target audience as below:
  • Developers: features, APIs, and architecture 
  • Consultants: flows, modules, and configuration 
  • Executives: business impact and how the Intelligent Enterprise helps companies run smarter 

This shift makes me more effective in stakeholder discussions, project planning, and skill development. 

Q: Looking back, what advice would you give your younger self or someone just starting their SAP journey? 

To my younger self, I‚Äôd say: ‚ÄúStart with basics, business processes, then explore SAP modules.‚Äù 

To newcomers: first understand real-world business challenges and processes, then learn Intelligent Enterprise concepts and SAP Business Suite flows. Everything else falls into place. 

Q: How has your learning impacted others at work or beyond? 

My journey has inspired juniors, peers, and even seniors to seek guidance for their SAP learning. 

Outside work, this led to invitations to podcasts, panels, and SAP events as a speaker. It also strengthened my credibility and reinforced my position as a thought leader in the SAP ecosystem. 

At this point, friends and colleagues joke: ‚ÄúJust Google his name, you‚Äôll find him.‚Äù 

Q: What‚Äôs been your proudest moment? 

Being recognized as one of SAP Champions worldwide was surreal and humbling. But I‚Äôm equally proud of helping colleagues grow, guiding careers, and creating a culture of continuous learning within my practice. 

Q: Bonus question: what‚Äôs the weirdest place you‚Äôve ever studied SAP? 

Definitely old bookshops on Bangalore‚Äôs streets, while hunting for novels. They gave me strange looks but for me, learning can happen anywhere. 

Q: And if your SAP learning journey were a movie? 

‚ÄúLearning Is Lifelong.‚Äù The moment you think you‚Äôve mastered it all, the technology changes and you realize you‚Äôre still a student. 

Kunal‚Äôs advice to every SAP learner: 

‚ÄúStart with what businesses need, not what buttons to click. SAP understanding, certifications and success will follow.‚Äù 

Ready to carve out your own daily hour? Explore learning journeys and certifications on the SAP Learning site  and see how far curiosity can take you.

entry.title: Overhead Accounting with Universal Parallel Accounting in SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Continuing the blog series on Universal Parallel Accounting and specifically the topic of Overhead Accounting, I‚Äôll now explain the changes introduced with SAP S/4HANA 2025.

If you read my original blog, you will recall that with Universal Parallel Accounting we extend the ledger approach to all financial applications, to ensure that the ledger settings are used consistently in Asset Accounting, Controlling and Actual Costing in addition to General Ledger Accounting. All value flows then take place with reference to this ledger, so allocations are ledger-specific to reflect the different inputs coming from Asset Accounting, General Ledger Accounting, and so on. If you build an activity-based model to charge costs to production or services, then the cost rates can also be ledger-specific, but the quantities themselves are captured only once.

Overhead Accounting with Universal Parallel Accounting 

With the initial delivery of Universal Parallel Accounting, SAP S/4HANA did not support indirect activity allocation (transactions KSC1-5) or template allocation (transactions CPT1-3, CPTA and CPTD) and if you tried to run these transactions, the system issued a message saying that the function was not supported because the business function for Universal Parallel Accounting was active. This changes with SAP S/4HANA 2025, where SAP supports indirect activity allocation and template allocation for environments 001 (Cost Estimate/Production Orders) and 009 (Process Orders).

Activity-Based Allocations

The simplest activity allocation is the direct activity allocation that is typically used to allocate costs between cost centers or from cost centers to orders and projects. Direct activity allocations were supported with the initial delivery of Universal Parallel Accounting to ensure the correct reporting of production and service costs. The amount of work performed is captured either using time recording, confirmations on the shop floor, or manually using transaction KB21N. Before you can record a direct activity allocation, you must define a cost rate for each unit of work and with the advent of Universal Parallel Accounting, this rate can be ledger-specific.

Indirect activity allocations, by contrast, are used when it is not possible to use confirmations or time recording to determine the amount of work performed, but instead you wish to allocate the total activity hours worked by a call center to the markets served or the total number of kilowatt hours supplied to your production cost centers.  There is no change to the way you set up an indirect activity allocation to calculate the quantities to be used as a basis for the allocation.  You can either manually enter the number of hours worked by the call center or have the system calculate the number of kilowatt hours supplied by looking at the machine hours on the receiving cost centers. The difference is that there can potentially be as many cost rates for these activities as you have set up ledgers.  While the amount-based allocations became part of universal allocation in SAP S/4HANA 2025, indirect activity allocation continues to use the legacy transactions KSC1-5 to manage and run the allocation cycles.

Template allocation is used instead of routings and recipes to calculate the amount of production activity expected. A template allocation might be as simple as determining that a setup or quality check is needed once for every production order or use its own function to calculate activity usage, so you might determine that shopfloor movements are dependent on the number of components in the bill of material (BOM) or the number of work center changes in the routing. Again, template allocation in SAP S/4HANA 2025 reuses the legacy transactions CPT1-3 to define the templates, and CPTA and CPTD to run the template allocation for production and process orders. This means that you can reuse any functions you may have created to determine whether an activity should be charged or to calculate the quantity of activity used.  As we saw for indirect activity allocation, you can potentially apply different cost rates for this quantity depending on the ledger.

With Universal Parallel Accounting the COST table becomes obsolete and is replaced by the ACCOSTRATE table with its link to the ledger. This means that you cannot use the legacy transaction KP26 to define the cost rates, but must use the Manage Cost Rates - Plan app or load the cost rates from SAP Analytics Cloud for Planning. Since the ACCOSTRATE table does not yet contain a field for the business process,  the sender object for an indirect activity allocation or a template allocation can only be the cost center/activity type combination and business processes (transactions CP01-03) are not yet supported.

Indirect Activity Allocation

At first glance, an indirect activity allocation looks like a distribution or assessment cycle, but the sender is not a cost center, but rather the combination of cost center and activity type and the sender rules are based on quantities (hence the link to the activity type) rather than amounts (where the cost center alone would be sufficient). In Universal Parallel Accounting, amount-based allocations are now executed using universal allocation, but quantity-based allocations continue to use the legacy transactions to determine the quantities used.

Figure 1 shows the segment header of an indirect activity allocation cycle to allocate kilowatt hours from an energy cost center to a group of production cost centers. You can access this screen using transaction KSC1. Notice that the segment uses the sender rule Quantities Calculated Inversely because we are going to use the total machine time recorded on the production cost centers to determine the number of kilowatt hours to be charged to each cost center. The receiver tracing factor is then Actual Activity, which in our case is the amount of machine time worked by the production cost centers. 

Figure 1: Segment Header of Indirect Activity Allocation Cycle

Indirect activity allocations build their charge model using different activity types from those used for direct activity allocations. Figure 2 shows the activity type for the allocation of kilowatt hours from the energy cost center. To perform the inverse calculation specified in the sender rule shown in Figure 1, you will need an activity type with Activity Type Category 2 (Indirect calculation, indirect allocation). Alternatively, if you don‚Äôt want to derive the quantity used from the receiver quantities but rather to spread an activity quantity that you have entered manually for your sender cost center, you‚Äôll need to create an activity type with Activity Type Category 3 (Manual Entry, Indirect Allocation) and switch the sender rule to Posted Quantities. You can then use transaction KB51N to capture the total quantity for the cost center/activity type combination to be allocated for the period.

Figure 2: Activity Type Master Record showing ATyp category 2 (Indirect determination, indirect allocation

Once you have defined the master data, you can enter the energy cost center in combination with the activity type for the kilowatt hours as the Sender and the production cost centers as the Receiver in the Senders/Receivers tab of the Indirect Activity Allocation Cycle as shown in Figure 3, thus establishing the relationship needed to run the allocation.

Figure 3: Senders and Receivers within Indirect Activity Allocation Cycle

Before you can run the allocation, you‚Äôll need to maintain an activity rate for the cost center/activity type combination using the Manage Cost Rates ‚Äì Plan app to calculate the initial rate as shown in Figure 4. You can choose whether you create different cost rates per ledger if the differences between the rates are significant or you can work with ledger-independent cost rates to simplify the planning process. Note that the ledger is not a default field, so to maintain ledger-specific cost rates in the Manage Cost Rates - Plan app, you will have to add the field to the layout using the View Settings button.

Figure 4: Ledger-Specific Cost Rates for Kilowatt Hours

Figure 5 shows the result of running the indirect activity allocation for the sender (the energy cost center).  The machine hours on the production cost centers have been used to derive the total kilowatt hours of energy used in the period and this is shown in the Actual Activity column.

Figure 5: Result of Indirect Activity Allocation, Showing Activity Quantity Assigned to Sender Cost Center and Activity Type

These quantities are valuated with the cost rates defined in Figure 4 and the Energy Cost Center debited and the Production Cost Centers credited under the G/L account associated with the activity type. You can identify such postings by searching for the Business Transaction Type RKIL in the Display Line Items app.  Figure 6 shows the postings from the energy cost center in ledger 0L. You can view the other documents by changing the ledger selection.

Figure 6: Ledger-Specific Line Items for Indirect Activity Allocation

Template Allocation

Template allocation is a more sophisticated way of including overhead costs in your product costs and assigning them to your production orders and process orders at period close. As I described in my previous blog, SAP has been moving various tasks out of the period close and making them event-based, but template allocation will continue to run at period close to allow customers to continue to use their existing functions to calculate the quantities used.

The Differences between Traditional and Event-based WIP and Variance Calculation  

Overhead calculation and template allocation are related and the system uses the costing sheet and overhead keys for overhead calculation to determine the template to be applied. Template allocation is particularly useful if you need to make sure that the outstanding balance on your cost centers is zero at the end of the period and all costs have been charged to production (a legal requirement in some parts of the world), when the use of percentage overhead rates almost always leaves a balance on the cost center at period close.

Templates are defined using transactions CPT1-3 and comprise a list of sender cost centers/activity types together with planned and actual quantities. The functions that can be called are grouped as environments, and the initial delivery will only support environments 001 (Cost Estimate/Production Orders) and 009 (Process Orders), with environments for WBS elements, networks and service orders planned for later.

You can either enter activity quantities to the template manually, such as one quality check per order, or have the system calculate them using formulas that read related driver quantities. SAP delivers a library of standard functions for each environment, and these can be extended as required. Additionally, you can set conditions that determine whether the activity is to be charged at all, so you might only charge a configuration activity if the material to be manufactured is configurable. This part of template allocation does not change with the move to Universal Parallel Accounting.

Template allocation is just a more dynamic form of direct activity allocation, so the activity types included in the template must have Activity Type Category 1 (Manual Entry, Manual Allocation), as shown for a Quality Check in Figure 7. This is the same setting as for the activity types you might use for order confirmation (setup, machine time, labor, and so on) or time recording (consulting hours, and so on).Figure 7: Activity Type Master Record showing ATyp category 1

As we saw for indirect activity allocation, you‚Äôll need to use the Manage Cost Rates - Plan app to enter a cost rate for the quality checks to be calculated by the template, as shown in Figure 8.

Figure 8: Ledger-specific Cost Rates for Quality Checks

Figure 9 shows a sample template to perform one quality check for each production order. The object in each case is the combination of cost center and activity type shown in the Object column. In this simple example the Plan quantity and Actual quantity we've entered a quantity of one manually, but you can also use functions to derive these quantities by clicking on the Plan Quantity or Actual Quantity column and choosing a function from the list. Here the charge will be applied in every period as the Plan activation and Actual activation columns are ACTIVE  but you can also use functions to determine the conditions under which a quality check should take place. 

Figure 9: Sample Template showing Activity Quantities

This template is linked to the cost estimate or the production order/process order via the combination of the costing sheet and overhead key as shown in Figure 10. 

Figure 10: Control Data for Production Order Showing the Costing Sheet and the Overhead Key

The link to the template is established in configuration (transaction KTPF) by linking the costing sheet and the overhead key with a template as shown in Figure 11.

Figure 11: Template Determination via Costing Sheet and Overhead Key

The cost center/activity type combinations entered in the template are automatically included in the standard cost estimate when you create a costing run using transaction CK40N or cost materials separately using transaction CK11N. Figure 12 shows a standard cost estimate (CK11N) with the template on the Valuation tab and the additional line for quality control in the itemization (Item No 22).

Figure 12: Sample Cost Estimate Showing Link to Template and Extra Line for Quality Check

For production orders and process orders you will need to run template allocation at period-close to collect the quantities relevant for allocation.  Template allocation is started using transaction CPTA for a single production order and CPTD for all orders in a plant. Figure 13 shows the result of running template allocation for a single production order with the template JS001 and cost rates in multiple ledgers.

Figure 13: Results of Template Allocation to Production Order

As the template allocation will result in additional costs on the production orders and process orders, you‚Äôll need to use the Postprocess Event-Based Posting - Product Costing app (F3369) to make sure that these additional costs are reflected in the work in process and production variances posted for your open production orders. Figure 14 shows the journal entries from template allocation as Items to Post in the Postprocess Event-Based Postings - Product Costing app. You can trigger additional postings for work in process and/or production variances by selecting the Post button.

Figure 14: Journal Entries from Template Allocation

Closing Words

This approach radically simplifies organizations‚Äô abilities to handle the requirements of different accounting principles in the area of overhead management and removes the need for significant manual work to reflect the different approaches on the true cost of goods sold.

Universal Parallel Accounting is still only delivered to pilot customers so it is important to compare the delivered scope with that required for your project, since functions that aren‚Äôt supported are not available in the SAP Easy Menu if the business function for universal parallel accounting is active.

If you are working with these types of allocation for the first time, please consider reading my detailed guide published by Rheinwerk Verlag.

Cost Flows in SAP S/4HANA Finance: Allocations and Settlements

entry.title: Get Ready for ASUG Tech Connect 2025 in Louisville: Don‚Äôt Miss Our Sessions and Innovations
entry.content:
ASUG Tech Connect is just around the corner, taking place November 4‚Äì6, 2025 in Louisville, Kentucky. This is your opportunity to stay ahead of the curve, connect with SAP executives and experts, and gain first-hand insights into the latest technologies shaping the future of business.

Customer Support & Cloud Lifecycle Management will be at the heart of the event‚Äîwith seven sessions led by our leaders, customers, and experts, plus two dedicated booths in the SAP area:

  • SAP Cloud ALM booth ‚Äì everything you need to know about implementation, operations, and transformation with SAP Cloud ALM.

  • Customer Support & SAP for Me booth ‚Äì discover how SAP is leveraging agentic AI, AI, and LLMs to transform customer support and deliver seamless experiences.

üëâWe‚Äôre frontrunners at SAP in applying these innovations, and ASUG Tech Connect is your chance to see them in action.

 

Don‚Äôt Miss These Sessions

November 4, 2025 | 11:15 AM ‚Äì 11:55 AM ET

Meijer‚Äôs AI Playbook: Resilience and Readiness for Peak Retail Moments
Join Meijer, ASUG‚Äôs Geoff Scott, and SAP‚Äôs Stefan Steinle to explore how AI-powered readiness safeguards business-critical operations. Hear how Carhartt ensures peak performance during high-demand periods, prevents risks before they impact, and turns seasonal pressure into a strategic advantage.
Speakers: Geoff Scott, Stefan Steinle, Customer

November 5, 2025 | 8:00 AM ‚Äì 8:50 AM ET

Transition from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM
Moving from SAP Solution Manager to SAP Cloud ALM? Explore the tools and best practices to ensure a smooth transition, including the ‚ÄúTransition to SAP Cloud ALM‚Äù roadmap, SAP Readiness Check, and selective data transfer tools.
Speakers: Umesh Jagadesh, Vijay Prakash

November 5, 2025 | 11:20 AM ‚Äì 12:10 PM ET

Using AI and Data-Driven Insights for a Smooth Customer Support Experience
See how autonomous agents, generative self-services, and intelligent automation are transforming SAP support experiences today and shaping the future with AI.
Speakers: Mohammed Ajouz, Alice Petrovich

November 5, 2025 | 1:00 PM ‚Äì 3:00 PM ET

Hands-on Lab: How to Start Transitioning to SAP Cloud ERP Private
Get guidance from the SAP Business Transformation Center and SAP Cloud ALM on moving to SAP Cloud ERP Private. Explore approaches, trusted advisor support, and integrated tools for a smooth journey.
Speakers: Thorsten Spihlmann, Kristin Aleksandrova, Jacqueline Hirsch, Oliver Huschke

November 5, 2025 | 1:50 PM ‚Äì 2:30 PM ET

SAP for Me: Unlock Personalized Insights Across Your SAP Landscape
SAP for Me is your personalized portal for insights and transparency. Learn how to monitor systems, access tailored recommendations, and upskill with guided learning.
Speakers: Mohammed Ajouz, Alice Petrovich

November 6, 2025 | 3:15 PM ‚Äì 4:05 PM ET

Adopt a Clean Core with SAP Cloud ALM and Extensions Built on SAP BTP
Learn how SAP Cloud ALM orchestrates the clean core journey with SAP BTP Best Practices. Manage requirements, testing, and release processes while staying current with innovation.
Speakers: Deepti Patil, Tim Steuer

November 6, 2025 | 4:15 PM ‚Äì 5:05 PM ET

Streamlining Transformation with SAP Cloud ALM, SAP LeanIX, and SAP Signavio
This session will explore how SAP LeanIX, SAP Signavio and SAP Cloud ALM enable organizations to drive smarter decision-making and accelerate digital transformation projects.
Speakers: Deepti Patil, Tim Steuer

 

Make It Part of Your Agenda

ASUG Tech Connect is about learning, connecting, and co-innovating. We encourage you to:

  • Register today if you haven‚Äôt already.

  • Add our sessions to your personal agenda to secure your seat.

  • Visit our booths in the SAP area to see the future of Cloud ALM and Customer Support in action.

We look forward to seeing you in Louisville this November‚Äîdon‚Äôt miss the chance to connect with our executives and experts, and experience how SAP is shaping the future of enterprise support with Cloud ALM, SAP for Me, and AI.

entry.title: Event trigger on post save, when LOA is entered in Job information portlet
entry.content:
Hello!

We have a requirement to trigger an ISC event whenever a Leave of Absence (LOA) or Return to Work (RTW) entry is made in the Job Information portlet.

Currently, the Leave Admin enters the LOA on behalf of the employee, which immediately sets the leave request to an Approved status. Because the request does not transition from Pending to Approved, the business rule is not triggered as expected.

Here‚Äôs a breakdown of the process:

  1. Leave Admin enters the LOA directly for the employee, setting the request to Approved.
  2. This action creates an LOA event in the Job Information portlet.
  3. Expected Behavior: A business rule should trigger on the post-save event based on changes in the Job Information model.
  4. Expected Outcome: The business rule should initiate an ISC event.
  5. Once triggered, the ISC event should send the required data to CPI via Integration Center.

Challenge: Since the LOA is entered directly in an approved state, the usual status transition that triggers the business rule does not occur.

Do you have any suggestions or workarounds to ensure the business rule and ISC event are triggered correctly in this scenario?

Any inputs or suggestions are greatly appreciated!

-Swathi

entry.title: The Complete Guide to Task Types in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
When you start working with SAP Cloud ALM, one of the first things you notice is that everything revolves around tasks.
Tasks define what needs to be done, by whom, when, and why. They help you keep track of your implementation journey whether you‚Äôre following SAP Activate methodology or managing a hybrid or agile project.

But here‚Äôs where it often gets confusing: there are different types of tasks, each serving a specific purpose, with different origins, dependencies, and usage scenarios.

This guide explains all SAP Cloud ALM task types, when to use them, where they come from, and how they fit together in simple terms.
Think of this as your definitive reference for Task Management in SAP Cloud ALM.

 

SAP Cloud ALM Task Types ‚Äì Unified Overview

 

Task Type

Purpose

 Typical Use

1. Roadmap TasksPredefined project steps based on the SAP Activate methodology.Guide project setup and execution (e.g., ‚ÄúDefine Scope‚Äù, ‚ÄúConduct Fit-to-Standard Workshops‚Äù).
2. Project TasksCustom, user-defined tasks for planning or coordination work not covered by roadmap.Organize team meetings, documentation, training, stakeholder briefings, or other ad-hoc tasks.
3. RequirementsHigh-level business needs that define what the solution should deliver.Capture stakeholder needs (e.g., ‚ÄúEnable digital vendor invoicing‚Äù) before breaking into stories.
4. User StoriesSmall, actionable work items derived from Requirements that describe how to deliver them.Assigned to teams for execution (e.g., ‚ÄúAs a user, I can upload invoices via Fiori app‚Äù).
5. Sub-TasksGranular breakdown of a User Story or Project Task into detailed steps.Track technical/configuration activities (e.g., ‚ÄúConfigure BAPI mapping‚Äù, ‚ÄúWrite unit test‚Äù).
6. DefectsLogged issues or bugs found during test execution or validation.Track and resolve test failures (e.g., ‚ÄúInvoice upload fails for large PDFs‚Äù).
7. Quality GatesPhase-end checkpoints to validate that required criteria have been met before moving forward.Enforce readiness before phase transition (e.g., ‚Äú80 % test pass rate‚Äù, ‚ÄúSign-offs complete‚Äù).
8. RisksIdentified threats that may impact project scope, schedule, or quality.Document, monitor, and mitigate risks (e.g., ‚ÄúData migration may delay testing if extract is late‚Äù).

 

When to Use Each Task Type

SAP Cloud ALM brings together different kinds of work from high-level project planning to detailed technical activities.
Here‚Äôs when and how to use each task type:

  • Roadmap Tasks ‚Üí Use these as your foundation. They come directly from SAP Activate and provide a ready-made list of best-practice activities for each phase (Prepare, Explore, Realize, Deploy).
  • Project Tasks ‚Üí Use these when you need to plan something unique to your project (for example, an internal workshop, report writing, or training sessions).
  • Requirements ‚Üí Use these early in the project to capture what your business wants to achieve. They define what needs to be done before you decide how to do it.
  • User Stories ‚Üí Create these once your requirements are approved. User Stories describe how the business need will be delivered.
  • Sub-Tasks ‚Üí Use them when your User Stories are too large or complex. They make it easier to assign smaller, clear responsibilities to team members.
  • Defects ‚Üí Use these during testing. Whenever a test fails or an issue arises, log a defect and link it to the related User Story or Requirement.
  • Quality Gates ‚Üí Use these at the end of each project phase. They ensure your team has met all exit criteria before moving to the next stage.
  • Risks ‚Üí Use them continuously. Risks can appear at any stage from project setup to go-live. Document, monitor, and mitigate them as the project evolves.

Task Sources ‚Äì Where Tasks Originate

SAP Cloud ALM doesn‚Äôt expect you to create every task manually.
Many tasks are automatically generated based on your project setup, methodology, or connected systems.

Here are the main task source types and where they apply:

 

Source Type

Description

Applies To

Setup TasksCreated automatically when you initiate a project in SAP Cloud ALM. Includes basic configuration and landscape setup tasks.Roadmap Tasks, Quality Gates
SAP Activate MethodologyPredefined tasks aligned with SAP Activate phases (Prepare, Explore, Realize, Deploy). Provides best-practice structure.Roadmap Tasks, Quality Gates
Manual or Excel UploadsTasks manually created by users or imported via Excel template for custom deliverables.Project Tasks, Sub-Tasks, Risks
Scoping TasksAutomatically generated when you select business processes during solution scoping.Requirements, User Stories
SAP Readiness CheckTasks derived from system analysis ‚Äî such as simplification items and custom code checks ‚Äî in conversion projects.Requirements, User Stories, Project Tasks
SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC)Read-only tasks synced from CBC that reflect configuration activities in cloud implementations.Roadmap Tasks, Project Tasks
Manual Creation in AppTasks created directly by users within the ALM apps (Tasks, Requirements, Risks, Defects).Project Tasks, Requirements, Defects, Risks
Test ExecutionAutomatically generates Defects when a test case fails.Defects
External
Tasks that originate outside of Cloud ALM (imported or synchronized via API or integration) or with Source=External in uploadProject Tasks, Requirements, User Stories

 

Putting It All Together ‚Äî How the Pieces Connect

Think of your project in SAP Cloud ALM as a pyramid of work:

  1. At the top, you have Roadmap Tasks , your standard methodology steps.
  2. Below them, Project Tasks capture custom activities.
  3. Requirements define the business goals.
  4. User Stories turn those goals into actionable items.
  5. Sub-Tasks break down the technical execution.
  6. Defects handle issues found during testing.
  7. Quality Gates control the flow between project phases.
  8. Risks run throughout, helping you manage uncertainty.

Everything is traceable from Requirement ‚Üí User Story ‚Üí Sub-Task ‚Üí Test ‚Üí Defect ‚Üí Quality Gate ‚Üí Go-Live.
This means you can see how every business need is implemented, tested, and delivered with confidence.

 

Summary: Why This Matters

 

Key Insight

Explanation

SAP Cloud ALM tasks connect every phaseYou can manage everything from planning to delivery in one system.
Automatic and manual sources complement each otherStandard tasks come from SAP Activate or CBC, while custom tasks adapt to your project‚Äôs reality.
Quality Gates and Risks ensure controlThey help enforce readiness and track uncertainties.
Traceability builds transparencyEvery requirement and test result links back to the task that drove it.
Beginner-friendly yet scalableStart simple with roadmap and project tasks, and grow into requirements and agile execution as your maturity increases.

 

Final Thought

When you understand task types in SAP Cloud ALM, you gain control of your entire project.
Instead of juggling spreadsheets, emails, and meetings, Cloud ALM gives you one connected framework where planning, execution, and quality all come together.

Use this guide as your reference every time you start a new implementation and you‚Äôll always know what to use, when to use it, and where it comes from.

entry.title: SAP Business Data Cloud - Model Size Analysis in SAC
entry.content:
A Clearer View of Your Data: Introducing the New Model Size and Analysis Dashboard for SAP Analytics Cloud

For administrators and system owners of SAP Analytics Cloud, maintaining a high-performing and stable environment is a top priority. As organizations expand their use of SAC, managing the underlying data volumes becomes increasingly important.

A technical consideration in this context are the database tables, which have a system limit of 2 billion records. Reaching this limit has a significant consequence: it blocks all data publishing for planning models.

Until now, gaining proactive visibility into this data growth has been a challenge. Administrators often faced key questions without easy answers:

  • Which of our hundreds of models are the largest and contributing most to our data footprint?
  • Is the growth coming from transaction data, or is the audit log expanding rapidly?
  • In our largest models, which specific versions (e.g., Forecast, Budget 2025) are consuming the most space?

Today, we are pleased to introduce a solution designed to provide clear answers to these questions.

How to access: Open the story in your tenant by going to the Side Menu > Performance > Model Size Statistics and Analysis.

Introducing the "Model Size Statistics and Analysis" Dashboard

Available with the 2025.QRC4 release, we are delivering a new Story in SAC Content designed to give you the transparency and control you need to manage your SAC tenant's data footprint effectively. This Story serves as a central overview for monitoring, analyzing, and then to be able to take an informed action on data volumes before they become a critical issue.

Let's explore its key capabilities.

Key Capabilities: From Overview to Actionable Insight

This new Story empowers you with a multi-layered analytical approach:

Instantly Identify Your Largest Models

The dashboard presents a clear, ranked list of your Top 30 Models by total record count. This immediately answers the fundamental question: "Where is my data?" This allows you to focus your attention where it's needed most, without guesswork or manual checks.

Understand Data Composition with Category Breakdowns

Once you select a model, the dashboard reveals a breakdown by Data Category. You can clearly see the ratio of Transaction Data, Audit Data, Master Data, and more. This is crucial for understanding the nature of your model's size. Is it growing because of massive data loads, or is it the audit trail from frequent planning activities?

Uncover Version-Level Insights (Even in Large Models)

This is a significant enhancement. Previously, for models exceeding 100 million records, it was not possible to see the size of individual public versions within the Modeler. The Model Size and Analysis dashboard removes this limitation. You can now select a large model and see a clear chart showing which versions are the biggest contributors. This provides the information you need to target specific versions for cleanup or archiving

.

Correlate Growth with System Actions

The dashboard provides historical charts that track record growth over time. More importantly, it overlays this data with Import Jobs and Version Publish Events. You can now visually correlate a spike in data with a specific data load or a major publishing cycle, creating a clear cause-and-effect relationship. This helps you understand why and when your data is growing, enabling you to optimize your data management processes.

The Business Value: More Than Just Numbers

This dashboard delivers tangible business value by transforming how you manage your SAC environment:

  • Ensure Business Continuity: By proactively monitoring the Audit and Fact table limits, you can prevent a system-wide pause on planning operations, safeguarding critical business processes.
  • Enable Proactive Housekeeping: Move from a reactive to a proactive stance. Analyze data growth trends, identify old or unnecessary versions, and perform timely cleanup actions to keep your tenant lean and performant.
  • Create Actionable Transparency: The dashboard doesn't just provide data; it provides answers. You can now confidently explain data growth and justify housekeeping activities to business stakeholders.
  • Reduce Resource Consumption & Improve Performance: A well-maintained tenant with optimized data volumes naturally performs better. By cleaning up unnecessary data, you reduce the load on the system, leading to a better experience for all users.

Get started today! Once your tenant is updated to 2025.QRC4, explore this new content and take command of your data. Empower yourself with the insight to ensure your SAP Analytics Cloud environment remains stable, performant, and ready for the future.

entry.title: Re: MMPV _closing the period - runtime error as 'DBSQL_DU...
entry.content:
Hi Ravi,

Since you've already implemented SAP Note 3202191 and the dump persists, here are some additional steps and considerations.

Identify the Affected Table : Use transaction ST22 to open the short dump and locate the specific table causing the error. Look for lines like INSERT <TABLE_NAME> or DBIF_DSQL2_ARRAY_INSERT.

Check for Custom Code or Enhancements
Review any custom developments, user exits, or BAdIs that might be interfering with period close logic. Look for recent transports or changes that could have introduced duplicate handling issues.

Review Number Range Overflows
Check if number ranges for relevant objects (e.g., accounting documents) are exhausted or overlapping.

Check for Duplicate Entries
Use SE11 or SE16 to inspect the table identified in the dump. Run a query to check for duplicate key entries. SELECT * FROM <TABLE_NAME> WHERE <KEY_FIELDS> = '<values>'

Manual Cleanup
If duplicates are confirmed and obsolete, you may consider deleting them using SE16N with edit mode (&SAP_EDIT). Always back up the table or consult SAP support before manual deletion.

Hope this have helped you resolve the issue of duplicate error

entry.title: Re: Diferen√ßa de valores entre lan√ßamento cont√°bil (FB03)...
entry.content:
Ol√°,
A discrep√¢ncia entre o valor da fatura no J1BNFE e o lan√ßamento cont√°bil no FB03 geralmente decorre da forma como o SAP lida com a avalia√ß√£o de materiais e a determina√ß√£o de pre√ßos, especialmente nos m√≥dulos Administra√ß√£o de Materiais (MM) e Contabilidade Financeira (FI).

Aqui est√° o que voc√™ pode pesquisar e considerar para explicar essa diferen√ßa:

Raz√£o de Materiais e Determina√ß√£o de Pre√ßos
Se o Raz√£o de Materiais estiver ativo, o SAP pode rastrear v√°rios pre√ßos (por exemplo, pre√ßo padr√£o, pre√ßo m√©dio m√≥vel). O pre√ßo usado na contabilidade (FB03) pode ser o pre√ßo m√©dio m√≥vel atual, enquanto a fatura (J1BNFE) reflete o pre√ßo no momento do pedido de compra ou do lan√ßamento da fatura. Verifique as configura√ß√µes do OMWB e a estrutura de determina√ß√£o de pre√ßos no MM.

Verifica√ß√£o de Faturas e Diferen√ßas de Pre√ßos
O SAP permite diferen√ßas de pre√ßos durante a verifica√ß√£o de faturas (MIRO), que s√£o lan√ßadas em uma conta de diferen√ßa de pre√ßos. Essas diferen√ßas podem surgir se o pre√ßo da fatura ‚â† o pre√ßo da ordem de compra ou o pre√ßo de avalia√ß√£o do material. Voc√™ pode verificar isso na guia Hist√≥rico de Pedidos de Compra ou no Hist√≥rico de Pedidos de Compra.

Momento das Atualiza√ß√µes de Pre√ßos
Mesmo que nenhuma altera√ß√£o manual de pre√ßo tenha sido feita, as atualiza√ß√µes autom√°ticas de pre√ßo (por exemplo, por meio de lan√ßamentos de EM ou faturas) podem afetar o pre√ßo m√©dio m√≥vel. O momento do lan√ßamento da fatura em rela√ß√£o ao lan√ßamento cont√°bil √© importante ‚Äî o SAP pode definir um pre√ßo diferente se a avalia√ß√£o do material mudar entre esses eventos.

Componentes de Imposto e Frete
√Äs vezes, o J1BNFE inclui impostos, frete ou outras condi√ß√µes que n√£o est√£o refletidas no documento cont√°bil. Verifique o procedimento de precifica√ß√£o e os tipos de condi√ß√£o na ordem de compra e na fatura.

Espero que isso tenha resolvido o problema.
